cards.definition: A necessary condition is one that must be present for another condition to occur. If P is true, then Q must be true.
A sufficient condition is one that, if met, guarantees that another condition occurs. If P is true, then Q is guaranteed to be true.
Being a male is a necessary condition for being a brother.
A number being divisible by 4 is sufficient for it to be even.
A condition that is both necessary and sufficient means that the condition is true if and only if another condition is true.

cards.description: Example of Necessary and Sufficient Condition
cards.definition: Today being the Fourth of July is necessary and sufficient for today being Independence Day in the United States.
In 'if P, then Q', Q is necessary for P and P is sufficient for Q.
For John to be a bachelor, it is necessary that he is unmarried, male, and an adult.
If John is a king, it is sufficient to conclude that he is male.
Necessity and sufficiency are dual to each other; if N is necessary for S, then S is sufficient for N.
